title: Path Lit by Lightning: The Life of Jim Thorpe
author: Maraniss, David*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very thorough, very long. I liked the portrayal of Jim in his younger years--his confidence and his attractive personality. I also loved his first wifVery thorough, very long. I liked the portrayal of Jim in his younger years--his confidence and his attractive personality. I also loved his first wife. His second wife was too young but I think they did love each other. His third wife was a promoter and very strong so that gets in the way of whether they were in love or not? At that point, Jim got a couple of facelifts. I thought that was sad. It was also sad that it took so long for the Olympic medals to get returned to the family (after his death). Another tragedy is that he is buried STILL in Pennsylvania rather than Oklahoma which was his wish. The story is spectacularly complicated but Jim holds his place in history and that is a good thing. The author mentioned several times how Jim was an unreliable narrator, not even clear on his own birthdate. The author describes trying to decipher what was mythology while doing his research. The end of the book was very hopeful as Jim's descendants have all gone on to make their positive mark on the world. The condescension toward Jim and making him into a "curiosity" are heartbreaking. Still, Jim just kept on going and did the best that he could. He was a great man. Videos I shared at the library when talking about this book:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0zVXH...https://davidmaraniss.com/about/ ...more

review: This is the 14th in the series. Don’t harm lovely Sully! The library details ring true again: the debate about which is better, the book or the movie?This is the 14th in the series. Don’t harm lovely Sully! The library details ring true again: the debate about which is better, the book or the movie?; the tenacity of a librarian wanting a lost book to be reunited with the owner; the portion of librarianship involved with rare books and restoration; the very fun (genius) subplot of having the library crafters simulate a book! I liked Lindsey & Sully taking the train to and from the conference. I liked how they watched the Hitchcock film, STRANGERS ON THE TRAIN, which I just watched today, spellbinding. I liked how the character of Robbie was correct about who the murderer was. The snowstorm was cleverly woven into the story to make a lot of things happen! Loved the final lines of the book, “In the end, wasn’t that all anyone could hope for? To know that they made a difference and to be remembered well.” Great job! ...more

Those are things librarians do well." SO COOL! Example of word play and fun on p. 147, "It stopped being an art school in 1939. It specialized in avantgarde--that's ultramodern--art. They had classes in Impossibleism, Supersurrealism, Dynamic Double-Daddy Realism, Ishkabibleism, and Mama." "Like Dada, only nicer." LOL. I learned something about Beaux-Arts architecture on p. 156. title: The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store
author: McBride, James*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: A very interesting book that I saw playing out like a movie in my head. I loved the relationship between two oppressed groups of people, Jewish peopleA very interesting book that I saw playing out like a movie in my head. I loved the relationship between two oppressed groups of people, Jewish people and African American people. I loved all the shady deals and the street smarts and the ability of the movers and shakers to get stuff done.My favorite character was Paper because she gathered people and gave them the news. Clever! I liked Miggy who was a powerful seer and learning about this subculture, LowGod. I found the gag present of the Cowboy traversing the ocean between Moshe and Malachi very charming. (The editorials about the future, p. 225/6 about smartphones and p.375 top about guns were random and offputting. Not that I don't agree but these thoughts snapped us out of the time and place and I did not like that.)Quotes I liked: p. 295 to 296 'Cause when the white man lays down his lying laws, he dines on the lie part of that fat meat while you and I get turned this way and that munching on the truth part. p. 297 bottom For if I was to raise a child, I would teach that child to love what I love and hate what I hate. p.45 He had no children, no car, no insurance policy, no bank account, no dining room set, no jewelry, no business, no set of keys to anything he owned, and no land. p. 64 Why are you worried if I'm a rebbe or not? So long as your words are uttered thoughtfully and with dull intent, it doesn't matter. Our ways give comfort rather than cause sorrow. They bring joy rather than pain. p. 26 Hilarious description of repressed white people dancing that begins with "The bands were horrible outfits that sounded like owls hooting."...more

title: The Collected Regrets of Clover
author: Brammer, Mikki*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Clover has a kind heart and she is very good to the dying in her role as a death doula. (I found out so much about that profession from this book and Clover has a kind heart and she is very good to the dying in her role as a death doula. (I found out so much about that profession from this book and I admire people in the field so much!) This is a lovely book about a lonely person who opens herself up to finding a good friend and also love from a good person. The author steers us in one direction for a long time and then things are switched up. I liked that! Clover's thoughts were very meaningful. p. 172 (@ a concert) That shared intimacy among strangers where, for just a moment, everyone laid aside the baggage of life to be completely present as one--a communal hopefulness.p. 173 To observe someone swept away by the thing they're most passionate about, most skilled at--what some call "flow"--is one of life's great privileges.p. 188 But gratitude doesn't necessarily free us from sadness--or our fears.p.197 (Observing others--giving them names--making up stories about them) Maybe a few minutes of Julia and Reuben would be the salve my racing mind needed.p.241 The truth is, grief never really goes away. Someone told me once that it's like a bag that you always carry--it starts out as a large suitcase, and as the years go by, it might reduce to the size of a purse, but you carry it forever. p. 250 I was a hypocrite. I spent my days looking death in the face and I still hadn't found a way to manage my own grief.p. 251 (She was learning in memory of...)I'd probably never have a use for Nepali either, but, in Jack's memory, I could learn the basics.p. 286 Your grief is yours to process in your own time, in whatever way works for you. No one can tell you how to do that.p. 290 You know, in Samoa some people believe that the spirits of loved ones stay with you even after they die, so you can still chat with them whenever you like.p. 304 Grief, I'd come to realize, was like dust. When you're in the thick of a dust storm, you're completely disoriented by the onslaught, struggling to see or breathe.p. 305 The secret to a beautiful death is living a beautiful life....more

title: Tom Lake
author: Patchett, Ann
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I don't usually focus on settings but this book painted the pictures of two settings so well that you felt like you were there. Tom Lake where the sumI don't usually focus on settings but this book painted the pictures of two settings so well that you felt like you were there. Tom Lake where the summer theater was and the cherry orchard where the family was reunited during Covid and doing the harvest together. This was a good reminder of how Covid actually was nurturing for some families. Even though it was stressful and there were so many unknowns, in lots of cases families joined up more and communicated more. Hopefully, they are keeping up that habit! I am not an OUR TOWN fan so I think I was soured on the book because OUR TOWN is so important in this story. I also felt that the narrator, Lara, spent too much time emphasizing that she is happy with her husband and three adult daughters and her life. I felt that she was trying to convince herself that this was true. An important truth of Lara's did not come out until almost the end of the book...it felt like a tag on. The burial of Duke's ashes was interesting and was a story device to create closure? I did not like Duke and I wish we knew more about him and why he was the way he was. I did like Sebastian, his brother. Duke reminded me of Tinker in RULES OF CIVILITY but I liked Tinker! haha...more

review: In this book, I did not care about either murder and I did not care about the missing books or why they were missing. Rather, I was caught up in the aIn this book, I did not care about either murder and I did not care about the missing books or why they were missing. Rather, I was caught up in the ambience and setting of the book which I loved. I loved the Scottish castle. I loved Mrs B and Tamara who have such good skills at making the guests welcome. I want them in my life, haha! I was interested in the customs of Hogmanay and First Footing. I was tickled that the bride and groom had LOVE SHACK for their song. So did I, in 1990! All of the clever ways to celebrate Christmas are things I took note of...red and green peppers in the scrambled eggs, red and green salsa with tortilla chips, fruits and veggies arranged as a Christmas tree (Alternate rows featured grapes and cantaloupe bits and chunks of cheddar cheese. Cherry tomatoes acted as ornaments on each end, and carrot sticks were bunched together to make the tree stand. A large piece of cauliflower was cut in the shape of a star and perched on top. It was delightful. p. 130), SWEET Christmas trees : Puff pastry where the wiggly tree part is smothered in cinnamon sugar and a hard chocolate square worked as a tree stand (p. 44), SAVORY Christmas trees: Goat cheese, sun-dried tomato pesto, garlic and oregano (p.45). I am inspired to make the season cozy and tasty!...more

title: The Authenticity Project
author: Pooley, Clare*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I loved this book! Thanks to Kim Leisgang for letting me know about it. It reminded me of other English books such as THE READING LIST and almost anytI loved this book! Thanks to Kim Leisgang for letting me know about it. It reminded me of other English books such as THE READING LIST and almost anything by Jojo Moyes. The book is fictional. It embraces multigenerational friendships and how being truthful will set you free. Julian is an elderly artist who is the impetus behind a notebook called THE AUTHENTICITY PROJECT. As the book lands in people's lives, they are willing to write down their truths in the book. Julian actually gets a new lease on life because the woman who finds the book (Monica) finds a way to have Julian teach art lessons in her restaurant. The chain continues with the remaining characters of the book. Then we return full circle to Julian who has closure because of the relationships he has created. Favorite quote from Mrs. Wu who I adored--she also grows in this book:"Tai chi is about the balance of yin and yang. If you use hardness to resist force, then both sides will break. Tai chi meets hardness with softness, so incoming force exhausts itself. It is philosophy for life, also."...more

title: We Have Always Lived in the Castle
author: Jackson, Shirley
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I listened to this book because it was mentioned in HOW CAN I HELP YOU? I liked the parts where the sisters were getting along and enjoying basic domeI listened to this book because it was mentioned in HOW CAN I HELP YOU? I liked the parts where the sisters were getting along and enjoying basic domestic life. I also liked the imagery of "being on the moon"...as in that would be a safe place to be. I really liked Merricat's use of sympathetic magic to protect the house, initially.  I was weirded out by Merricat's forcefulness when she spoke about wanting to kill people. The poisoning which happened within the family was startling. Merricat and Constance and Uncle Julian (the survivors) are living together although Julian is old and ailing. A cousin, Charlie, shows up but then a fire takes down the house. The neighbors vandalize the home after the fire. This was terrifying. There is definitely a rift between the family and the others in the village. There is some redemption when the neighbors start dropping off food for Constance and Merricat.From Wikipedia: The town is "pretty recognizable as North Bennington, Vermont" where Jackson and her husband, Bennington professor Stanley Edgar Hymen, encountered strong "reflexive anti-Semitism and anti-intellectualism." ...more

title: Christmas Cricket
author: Bunting, Eve
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Cricket brings his joyful noise to the place he has hidden himself in in a Christmas tree.  I have always been amazed by the body of work that Eve BunCricket brings his joyful noise to the place he has hidden himself in in a Christmas tree.  I have always been amazed by the body of work that Eve Bunting has contributed to children's literature. This Irish woman who transplanted to California and became an author passed away on October 1, 2023 at the age of 94. My top two favorites by her are THE WEDNESDAY SURPRISE and HAPPY BIRTHDAY, DEAR DUCK. We miss you Eve Bunting. Thanks for all of your stories.There are several key factors to her writing that I see: *compassion *humor *a reverence for the ordinary moments *respect for nature *the willingness to tackle very tough subjects *offering solutions *everything presents a story!*Eve was assigned a different illustrator for each of her books. Miraculously, each match fits perfectly. ...more

Set in Frankenmuth, Michigan, “Little Bavaria”, which is a real place BTW! The young woman comes home from a high paying cutthroat job to her small town which embraces Christmas and where her parents run a Christmas shop. She is there to convince them to sell it (for her boss) and is reunited with her high school sweetheart. Interestingly, the protagonist is 52. Also, Viola Shipman is the pen name of Wade Rouse. Very good sweet messages even though you definitely know the endings from the beginning. ...more

title: Mr. Dickens and His Carol
author: Silva, Samantha*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The author decided to write a novel to pay tribute to Dickens but also freely admits that she took lots of liberties. It is true that Dickens was a suThe author decided to write a novel to pay tribute to Dickens but also freely admits that she took lots of liberties. It is true that Dickens was a super star of his day and yet was destitute because so many people asked him for money. In this story, he is desperate to write a really good Christmas book to please his publishers and make profits. He is on a very tight deadline. His wife takes the children to Scotland and he meets a woman named Eleanor. Her and her son inspire him with his ideas for A Christmas Carol. There is a huge surprise in the final third of the book which I will not spoil. I will admit, this book was a slow start for me but I enjoyed it each page that I got further into it. ...more

author: Langsdorf, Julie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Primarily focuses on three middle-aged couples--their challenges and their dreams. I liked that the author gave us insights into the six individuals--Primarily focuses on three middle-aged couples--their challenges and their dreams. I liked that the author gave us insights into the six individuals--what they were grappling with. The plot is about perceived societal expectations and personal expectations. The same applies to the youth in the book. We watch as they are wrestling with school and friendship in a reflection of the struggles of the adults. The storyline portrays the overlapping that happens in a community but also the nostalgia experienced by the people who grew up in it. There is a sense of peace at the end of the book but we know that will only last so long!...more

title: How Can I Help You
author: Sims, Laura*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Yowzer! Nasty! Macabre! Set in a library. Fast read. The two protagonists Margot (Jane) and Patricia are two sickies. Margot is a former nurse serial Yowzer! Nasty! Macabre! Set in a library. Fast read. The two protagonists Margot (Jane) and Patricia are two sickies. Margot is a former nurse serial killer (Yuck!) now beginning a new life with a new identity and working at a public library. She doesn't read (haha) but convinces herself to read Shirley Jackson's WE HAVE ALWAYS LIVED IN THE CASTLE when she sees Patricia looking at it. (And, of course, I have to read that now, too.) Patricia is a reference librarian, fresh out of school, who really only wants to write a bestseller. Patricia finds out Margot's true identity and uses her AS HER MUSE. (Yuck!) Comparisons to author Shirley Jackson are justified by the climax of the story. So weird but a solid read. The reference questions are hilarious and what really happens sometimes! Did not even known about this book until Cindy pointed it out. Thanks! Had to do some research on JOLLY JANE who was the impetus for the book. From the NEW ENGLAND HISTORICAL SOCIETY: "Today, psychiatrists say she was one of the most unusual serial killers in history. Like many serial killers, she had an unstable childhood. Unlike most female serial killers, she did it for the sexual thrill.As her victims lay dying, she got a powerful erotic charge from holding and caressing them." Written by a public librarian, congrats to her!...more

title: Murder Under a Red Moon        (Kaveri and Ramu, #2)
author: Nagendra, Harini*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Very good! I continue to love the character of Kaveri. And somehow I missed this in the first book but she is only 19 years old!! How she uses math prVery good! I continue to love the character of Kaveri. And somehow I missed this in the first book but she is only 19 years old!! How she uses math problems to "clear her mind" is charming! The Swami is smarmy and Kaveri picks up on this immediately. I loved how Kaveri is trying so hard to get closer to her mother-in-law (Bhargavi) and lo and behold her mother-in-law is beginning to respect Kaveri's detective work. I love the introduction of Putta, the dog, as an example of accepting a new idea into one's life. We continually visit the difference between the impoverished and the wealthy in this book. The scene where the street urchins are paid to gather rats (as a fight against cholera) is very vivid to me. The scene where Kateri loses control of her sabotaged car was super frightening! The author brings in historical notes such as India's pending fight for independence from Britain. (This is set in 1920s Bangalore.) She also draws the pictures of so many women and their struggles but also their solidarity. This feminist enjoys how easily she does that! We also learn about the scourge of cocaine. Whatever Kaveri is working on, she is always wearing a sari!My favorite quote was on p. 238: "I was thinking of the night I saw the blood moon in the sky, the day Mr. Sharma died. Your mother and so many others believe that the eclipse takes place when the demon Rahu swallows the moon. And yet our own mathematicians like Aryabhata showed how eclipses occur using principles of geometry 1500 years ago. We all see the same eclipse, but deduce different stories to explain how it happens. What are the truths we miss when we see a murder, and try to judge who is responsible?"...more

title: Streets of Gold: America's Untold Story of Immigrant Success
author: Abramitzky, Ran
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I enjoyed the audio version of this book read by Rachel Botchan. A great case for the positives of immigration in all of its waves. This book is steepI enjoyed the audio version of this book read by Rachel Botchan. A great case for the positives of immigration in all of its waves. This book is steeped in research, statistics, and data that was painstakingly gathered by the authors. I learned about college educated immigrants who are immediately upwardly mobile. I learned about children of immigrants who surpass their parents greatly and are very successful in our society as well as assimilate rapidly. There was a wonderful chapter in the book about how rich America is because of all the different people who live here. Examples: The choices of ethnic food and fusions cannot be beat here! It is also the same case with all the different kinds of music available to us as well as new music being developed all the time! The book ends strong with the image of the Statue of Liberty still being a positive symbol!...more

review: Bear thinks he is making all of the autumn things happen with his sneezes (leaves falling, apples dropping, geese flying). In a stand off with the winBear thinks he is making all of the autumn things happen with his sneezes (leaves falling, apples dropping, geese flying). In a stand off with the wind, wind gives bear a stern lesson that the power is coming from it, the AUTUMN BREEZE. By the end of the book, bear knows it is not his sneeze, but the breeze, that slams the door of his den. SLJ : "An above-average addition for libraries looking for more bear, hibernation, or winter stories to freshen up interactive storytimes." Yes!...more

title: Save What's Left
author: Castellano, Elizabeth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The couple in the book seem to share a mid-life crisis. Tom leaves on a global trip and Kathleen buys beachfront property. She gets caught up in all sThe couple in the book seem to share a mid-life crisis. Tom leaves on a global trip and Kathleen buys beachfront property. She gets caught up in all sorts of entanglements with local authorities and Tom eventually finds his way back to her. The author seems young to have such insights into mid-life. But I am here to say that her details are accurate AND funny. In a letter to her Town Supervisor (she writes many such letters without any responses) she says, "I don't want to get into all the details, but I'm proud to say that I can now add becoming a person of interest in a racketeering, bribery, and money-laundering investigation to the ever-growing list of horrible things that have happened to me since moving to Whibey." IJBOL! Fun, fast read....more
